title.value: DeltaShield: Information Theory for Human-Trafficking Detection
title.justification: The title "DeltaShield: Information Theory for Human-Trafficking Detection" is explicitly stated at the beginning of the document, providing the complete and precise title of the research paper.
title.quote: DeltaShield: Information Theory for Human- Trafficking Detection

extractions.description: The paper introduces InfoShield, a method that employs information theory to identify micro-clusters of near-duplicate documents, which can signal human trafficking. It extends the method to DeltaShield for incremental updates. The approach is scalable, parameter-free, interpretable, and generalizable, providing high precision and interpretability, especially in the anti-human trafficking domain.

type.justification: The paper discusses experiments conducted on real datasets (Twitter data and HT ads) to demonstrate the effectiveness and scalability of InfoShield.
type.quote: Our experiments on real data show that InfoShield correctly identifies Twitter bots with an F1 score over 90% and detects HT ads with 84% precision.

name.justification: The primary focus is on detecting anomalies such as human trafficking by identifying micro-clusters of similar ads, which is a task related to anomaly detection.
name.quote: CCS Concepts: • Computing methodologies → Anomaly detection; • Information systems → Clustering;

name.justification: The paper involves clustering related documents to detect micro-clusters of related ads.
name.quote: Finding related documents is a problem with numerous applications, such as search engines, plagiarism detection, mailing address de-duplication, and more.

name.justification: The technique involves mining textual data to detect patterns signaling human trafficking.
name.quote: Additional Key Words and Phrases: Text mining, minimum description length (MDL), anti-human trafficking detection

name.justification: The paper employs machine learning methods to handle clustering and anomaly detection tasks on text data.
name.quote: InfoShield is general, using no language-specific or domain-specific features...This makes our method very powerful; it can be run on text in almost any language, or on other text data such as DNA strings.

name.justification: HTDN is mentioned as a deep multimodal model for classifying ads for human trafficking, which is compared against InfoShield in the paper.
name.quote: For instance, HTDN [52] proposes a supervised deep multimodal model trained on 10K manually labeled ads.

is_contributed.justification: HTDN is referenced as an existing model for comparison, not as a contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: For instance, HTDN [52] proposes a supervised deep multimodal model...

is_executed.justification: HTDN is not executed within the scope of the paper; it is mentioned for comparison purposes only.
is_executed.quote: For instance, HTDN [52] proposes a supervised deep multimodal model...

is_compared.justification: HTDN is explicitly compared to InfoShield in terms of performance on the Trafficking10k dataset.
is_compared.quote: The Trafficking10k dataset is created in the work of Tong et al. [52], where expert annotators manually labeled 10,265 ads.... For HT data, we see that InfoShield reports the highest precision...

referenced_paper_title.value: Combating Human Trafficking with Multimodal Deep Models
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper in which HTDN was described is mentioned to acknowledge its origin and relevance to the domain.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For instance, HTDN [52] proposes a supervised deep multimodal model...

name.justification: The dataset Trafficking10k is explicitly mentioned as a dataset used in the work to evaluate the models.
name.quote: The Trafficking10k dataset is created in the work of Tong et al. [52], where expert annotators manually labeled 10,265 ads from 0 to 6.

referenced_paper_title.value: Combating Human Trafficking with Multimodal Deep Models
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Trafficking10k dataset is linked to the work mentioned in this paper as being relevant to the discussion about HTDN models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Trafficking10k dataset is created in the work of Tong et al. [52], where expert annotators manually labeled 10,265 ads from 0 to 6.

name.justification: Cluster Trafficking dataset is directly referenced in the experiments section of the paper.
name.quote: Cluster Trafficking consists of 157,258 ads, with 6,283 spam ads, 50,985 HT ads, and 99,990 normal ads.

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no external referenced paper for Cluster Trafficking; it seems to be introduced specifically for this work's context.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Cluster Trafficking consists of 157,258 ads, with 6,283 spam ads, 50,985 HT ads, and 99,990 normal ads.
